Award.AwardTitle: GPG: Collaborative Research: REU Pilot: Synthetic Biology Bootcamp
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award has been made to Simmons College in Boston, MA and Carthage College in Kenosha, WI to pilot a summer "boot camp" in synthetic biology. This award will support training of eight students at each site during the summer of 2015. Students trained in the program will gain skills in lab research, develop their critical thinking and problem-solving skills, understand the process of science, and be able to communicate their research results to their peers and the general public. Students will have an opportunity to present their results at a national conference. Students from schools with limited opportunities for research and from underrepresented groups are encouraged to apply.

This collaborative proposal will test the effectiveness of intensive instruction in the interdisciplinary area of synthetic biology and ask if the boot camp prepares students to participate in future research experiences in synthetic biology. The other goal of this proposal is to determine if a dispersed, collaborative effort between two primarily undergraduate institutions can serve as a model for a future REU Sites proposal. The focus of the boot camp will be lecture, computer lab and "wet-lab" research to design genetic circuits in living organisms. The PIs participated in a GCAT Synthetic Biology workshop during the summer of 2013, and they will model their program after this workshop. The main research question will be to design organisms that can sense hydrocarbon contaminants in water from different sources. During the four week program, students will participate virtually in activities including bio-ethics, lab meetings, journal clubs, and career opportunities. At the end of the program, students will present their research in a virtual poster session.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by contacting either of the PIs, Dr. Jennifer Roecklein-Canfield (at jennifer.canfield@simmons.edu) or Dr. Deborah Tobiason (at dtobiason@carthage.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In June 2015, a collaborative synthetic biology bootcamp was run between Carthage College and Simmons College to introduce research topics in Synthetic Biology to undergraduates and to assess the feasibility of creating a collaborative REU model between predominately undergraduate institutions. Eight undergraduate students were selected to participate at each school, four from within the home institution and four from outside colleges. A goal of the bootcamp was to expose to students to the interdisciplinary nature of Synthetic Biology by including topics from biology, computer science and mathematics. To that end, half of the students participating had biology backgrounds while half had computer science or biostatistics backgrounds. The biology students helped the math/computer science students in the laboratory to create a biosensor, while the computer science patiently worked with the biology students as they were exposed to computer programming in Python.  The students came away with a greater understanding and appreciation for the different scientific disciplines, in that the biology students now have a sense of the importance of creating specific programs to aid in addressing their research questions and the math/computer science students now can recognize the biological application of their work.  This cross-disciplinary approach has resulted in several students now considering majoring/minoring in one of the newly explored fields. The students realize that being a computer programmer with knowledge of biological questions can lead to even greater opportunities for them in the future.

The focus of the bootcamp research was to build a toluene biosensor that potentially could be used to detect toluene and other benzene derivatives in contaminated water. The collaborative groups at Carthage and Simmons College interacted virtually several times a week in lab meetings and workshops using videoconference software such as Skype and in small group discussions between students at each school using Facebook.  The students were placed into research groups composed of two students from each institution.  This fostered additional collaboration and interaction.  The Carthage students were able to hear about the levels of toluene and its derivatives in the Muddy River in Boston, while the Simmons students were able to benefit from a workshop with the bioethics instructor at Carthage. In addition, the faculty interacted daily via messaging and over the phone to discuss the daily activities and prepare for the next steps in the biosensor construction. These interactions built a small research community for everyone involved and gave a greater sense of purpose to the students in the research that they were doing.

The research focus was to construct a toluene biosensor in E. coli based upon previous studies from Stiner and Haverson (2002) and iGEM construction techniques.  The objectives were to expose the students to the laboratory techniques related to Synthetic Biology, drawing from biology, molecular biology, microbiology, and biochemistry.  The students were able to clone the biosensor cassette into the iGEM vector backbone and attempted to clone the cassette into reporter gene plasmids. Though the complete biosensor was not constructed in four weeks, the goals of the bootcamp were met in that it was determined that running a collaborative, pre-REU bootcamp is feasible and the impact upon students interest in interdisciplinary research was positive
